articles.title: Above-normal temperatures continue through the week
articles.author: Samuel Kirk
articles.summary: Warm and dry conditions will dominate the region this week. High pressure over the Desert Southwest is responsible for the warming trend. By midweek, a weak weather disturbance will bring breezier conditions, possibly leading to elevated fire weather concerns due to the ongoing dry conditions. Temperatures will start to trend downward at the weekend.

articles.title: China defends live-fire drills that forced flight path changes
articles.author: Jake Nelson
articles.summary: China has accused Australia of overreacting to live-fire military drills in the Tasman Sea on Friday that forced changes to commercial flight paths. The Chinese defence ministry said Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Defence Minister Richard Marles had made statements 'completely inconsistent with the facts' on Saturday.

articles.title: Russia hit with more sanctions three years on from war
articles.author: Tess Ikonomou
articles.summary: Australia has slapped further travel bans and sanctions on Russian individuals and entities three years after the invasion of Ukraine and three years on from the full-scale invasion of the Ukraine.      Â   in Australia has slapped travel bans, sanctions and bans on Russian people and entities.

articles.title: Climate change worsening psychological trauma, expert warns
articles.author: Felix Oloyede
articles.summary: Dr Chima Okoro, a psychologist from the University of Lagos, says climate change contributes to the rise of psychological trauma in the country. He was speaking at the 2025 Trauma International Community of Practice organised by the Bible Society of Nigeria in Lagos on Wednesday and Thursday, February 18-19, 2025. The President of the society, Bishop Timothy Banwo, described trauma as a barrier to scriptural engagement. The ongoing economic challenges, insurgency, banditry, and kidnapping have heightened the prevalence of trauma among Nigerians.

articles.title: Spark Study Buddy (Challenger): Climate change may increase human-snake contact
articles.author: We Cover The Latest News
articles.summary: Last year was the warmest on record, according to the European Copernicus climate service. The more the world warms, the worse the impacts of climate change will be. Wildlife will be affected by rising temperatures, including snakes. There are 53 species of snakes in Hong Kong. About 40 per cent of the land is designated as country parks.

articles.title: FARMER: Spring is coming
articles.summary: I am tired of the cold February temperatures. Spring is coming and soon the buds on the trees will be transforming into fresh new leaves. Beautiful flowers and blossoms will begin blooming and filling the air with pleasant fragrances. Baby birds will be hatching in their nests and crying for food. Canadian honker geese will migrate north and the grass will turn green.

articles.title: Fast-unfolding climate change crisis, climate tipping points, and early warning system
articles.author: Dr Omer Javed
articles.summary: The writer holds PhD in Economics degree from the University of Barcelona, and previously worked at the International Monetary Fund. The consensus reached at the Paris Agreement in 2015 was to limit temperature globally to below 1.5C, and not allow it to reach anywhere near 2C. Since then, the leading scientific body, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, has modelled. This indicates that the climate change crisis is happening at a much higher pace than before. Global financial architecture is ill-equipped to address the climate crisis. Mi a Amor Mottley is pushing the case for providing climate finance under the Bridgetown Initiative.

articles.title: Studies indicate high threat of glacial lake burst in Kullu, Lahaul
articles.author: Pratibha Chauhan
articles.summary: There is a danger of glacial lake outbursts due to climate change and accelerated melting of glaciers. The Parbati river in Kullu district is most vulnerable to floods. The Ghepang Ghat Lake (4,068 m) in Lahaul and Spiti has expanded by 178 per cent in the past 33 years.

articles.title: Future economic development in Maine: Are there limiting factors?
articles.author: Dr. John M. Mishler
articles.summary: The California tragedy is a wake-up call for Maine to prepare for climate change. Five of the 10 hottest years in Maine's recorded history have occurred from 2000-2024. Maine has introduced solutions/options focused on reducing carbon dioxide/methane concentrations, by utilization of electric vehicles, installation of wind/solar farms and increasing energy-efficient homes.

articles.title: The new American political revolution and what it means for Australia
articles.author: system
articles.summary: The challenge presented to Australia by the second Trump presidency is about more than foreign policy and defence. The end game of the Trump administration is unpredictable and unpredictable.    “The end game is unpredictable”, as Donald Trump said in his speech.

articles.title: Preservation of cultural heritage sites in Nigeria
articles.author: Ojebiyi Roseline
articles.summary: Nigeria is home to numerous cultural heritage sites, which reflect its rich history, diverse ethnic traditions, and artistic achievements. These sites include UNESCO World Heritage Sites, ancient monuments, archaeological sites, and traditional cultural landscapes. Climate change in Nigeria is a growing environmental and socio-economic challenge, with significant impacts on agriculture, water resources, health, and cultural heritage.

articles.title: Nations at odds over major UN climate science report
articles.author: Kelly MACNAMARA
articles.summary: Representatives of nearly 200 countries are meeting in Hangzhou to discuss the timing and content of the UN's next blockbuster assessment of global warming science. The meeting comes on the heels of the hottest year on record and rising alarm over the pace of warming. Donald Trump's withdrawal of the United States from the Paris Agreement will also cast a shadow over the talks.

articles.title: Nations at odds over major UN climate science report
articles.author: Kelly MACNAMARA
articles.summary: Representatives of nearly 200 countries gather in Hangzhou to discuss the UN's next blockbuster assessment of global warming science. The meeting comes on the heels of the hottest year on record and rising alarm over the pace of warming, which has been caused by climate change.

articles.title: Nations at odds over major UN climate science report
articles.author: Kelly MACNAMARA
articles.summary: Representatives of nearly 200 countries gather in Hangzhou on Monday to discuss the UN's next global warming assessment. Donald Trump's withdrawal from the Paris Agreement will also cast a shadow over the meeting, as reports suggest Washington will not send a delegation to the five-day meeting.

articles.title: Chemtrails Are Killing All Life On Planet Earth
articles.author: Alicia Lutz-Rolow
articles.summary: The WEF Globalist Technocrats are trying to destroy all life on Earth. They use weather as a weapon on other nations and on the American people. They want to depopulate the world so they get to kill people and make money at the same time. They blame the people for their CO2, their cows and their utility use.

articles.title: A powerful force is stopping the Indian Ocean from cooling itself – spelling more danger for Ningaloo
articles.author: Kelly Boden-Hawes
articles.summary: There is widespread coral bleaching at Ningaloo Reef off Western Australia's coast due to a marine heatwave. More than 30,000 fish have died since the September onset. La Nina and its opposite, El Nino, influence ocean temperatures and weather patterns across the Pacific.

articles.title: North Buncombe High School students lead recovery efforts for NC farmers post-Hurricane Helene
articles.author: Lora Lavigne
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene hit western North Carolina four months ago. The storm devastated crops, equipment and land. The students at North Buncombe High School in the Future Farmer's of America (FFA) program have stepped up to help provide aid. They have turned their shop class into a grocery store and greenhouse into a shopping center, distributed grants and delivered care kits to nursing homes. They distributed barbed wire and fence posts to local farms still in need of fencing repairs.

articles.title: Experts urge tactics to reinforce climate resilience in agriculture
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: Farmers are facing erratic weather patterns, severe temperatures and water deficiency due to climate change. The agricultural industry is on the frontline of the climate change crisis, according to Mafna.   Â. Â   y   in Menafna

articles.title: Moving Glacially
articles.author: Willis Eschenbach
articles.summary: Willis Eschenbach is skeptical about the current climate change alarmism. In 1678, Swiss burghers in the villages of Fiesch and Fieschertal petitioned Pope Innocent XI to stop the advance of the Aletsch Glacier. In 2010, Pope Benedict XVI approved the petition.

articles.title: Experts come up with a slew of strategies to keep the city cool
articles.author: R. Aishwaryaa
articles.summary: Chennai residents are concerned about the unbearable summer followed by large-scale flooding. Experts attribute the rising temperature and flooding to rapid urbanisation that reduce the green cover and the spread of waterbodies. Experts have recommended improved land use planning, better maintenance of water bodies, and more effective solid waste management strategies.

articles.title: Experts come up with a slew of strategies to keep Chennai cool

Experts attribute the rising temperature and flooding to rapid urbanisation that reduce the green cover and the spread of waterbodies. Experts have recommended improved land use planning, better maintenance of water bodies, and more effective solid waste management strategies.

articles.title: Climate researchers should play the Trump card
articles.author: Guardian Staff
articles.summary: There is an outcry as American researchers have had their grants withdrawn for projects containing the word 'climate'. Vanessa Rickett received an otherwise good school report when she was 14 and her art teacher said that Steven is too easily satisfied by a mediocre standard of work. Sarah Hall feels the Duchess of Sussex's rebranding effort 'As Ever' is a little too close to 'Whatever'.

articles.title: ‘Nuclear carbon emission bomb': 2b tonne greenhouse gas surge forecast under Coalition
articles.author: David Crowe
articles.summary: Coalition's plan for nuclear energy would increase greenhouse gas emissions by more than 2 billion tonnes in the next 25 years, according to new modelling from the Climate Change Authority. The findings heighten the dispute over the nuclear policy under which Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says a Coalition government would build seven nuclear power stations at a cost of $331 billion by 2050.

articles.title: Heat Wave Warning Issued for Kenya and Eastern Africa
articles.author: Martin Olage
articles.summary: Kenya and the wider Eastern African region are bracing for a significant heat wave. The areas expected to experience the most intense heat stress include Eastern Kenya, South Sudan, Eastern Tanzania, Southern Sudan and Southern Somalia. Southeastern Sudan is projected to face temperatures exceeding 32°C. Some relief is expected in Northern Sudan, the Ethiopian highlands, and Central and Western Kenya.

articles.title: Cool change eases fire risk as popular track reopens
articles.summary: A cool change is bringing relief to parts of Australia's southeast. A total fire ban in Tasmania expired at 2am on Monday. A hiking track will reopen to bushwalkers on Monday after it was shut for more than two weeks due to a nearby bushfire on Canning Peak, in the state's west.

articles.title: Cool change eases fire risk as popular track reopens
articles.author: William Ton
articles.summary: A cool change is bringing relief to parts of Australia's southeast. A total fire ban declaration in Tasmania expired at 2am on Monday. A hiking track will reopen to bushwalkers on Monday after it was shut for more than two weeks due to a nearby bushfire on Canning Peak. A band of thunderstorms helped cool temperatures in Victoria. High-pressure system is forecast to move across southeast Australia on Monday, bringing warmer conditions mid-week.

articles.title: Cool change eases fire risk as popular track reopens
articles.author: William Ton
articles.summary: A cool change is bringing relief to parts of Australia's southeast. Fire crews are bracing for potential new blazes amid a spell of hot weather, but the change is good news for them.    in this case, the cool weather is good for fire crews.

articles.title: Cool change eases fire risk as popular track reopens
articles.summary: A cool change is bringing relief to parts of Australia's southeast. A total fire ban in Tasmania expired at 2am on Monday. The Overland Track will reopen to bushwalkers on Monday after it was shut for more than two weeks due to a nearby bushfire on Canning Peak in the state's west.

articles.title: Former FEMA head Brock Long and heat policy expert Ashley Ward at App State Feb. 25
articles.author: Kenneth Reece
articles.summary: The forum takes place on Tuesday, February 25 at 12:30 p.m. in Room 420 (Parkway Ballroom) of the Plemmons Student Union at Appalachian State University. The event is free of charge and open to the public. The forum is part of App State's Pathways to Resilience initiative. Speakers are Brock Long, former FEMA administrator and Ashley Ward, director of the Heat Policy Innovation Hub at Duke University.

articles.title: Setting climate action in order
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: There is a rapid acceleration in the melting of glaciers, with 36% higher ice loss between 2012 and 2023 than what occurred between 2000 and 2011. The loss varies between regions, with the European region losing more ice than the rest of the world, according to Nature.

articles.title: Sea-level rise: a new method to estimate the probability of different outcomes – including a worst case
articles.author: Benjamin P. Horton
articles.summary: Sea-level rise will continue to threaten ecosystems, communities and cities. The exact rate and magnitude of future sea-level rises is deeply uncertain. Different methods produce different projections of long-term sea- level rise. A new method combines the complementary strengths of different projections. It allows us to estimate a'very likely' range.

articles.title: Indonesia glaciers may vanish by 2026 due to global warming: expert
articles.author: Kyodo
articles.summary: Indonesia's only glaciers could disappear by next year due to global warming. The glaciers are on the 4,862-meter-high peak Puncak. The phenomenon may affect the island's flora and fauna including indigenous species. The decline has been significant.

articles.title: Why climate must be at the core of global commerce
articles.summary: Chung Keeyong is an ambassador and the deputy minister for Climate Change at the Korean Ministry of Foreign Affairs. He believes trade and climate policy are at a crossroads as economies grapple with rising emissions, shifting industries and urgent sustainability needs. The Elders' open letter calls for reforming climate negotiations.

articles.title: January 2025 Sees Record Global Temperatures
articles.author: Editorial Staff
articles.summary: According to the Copernicus Climate Change Service and the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, January 2025 was 1.75°C above the pre-industrial level. According to the World Meteorological Organization, the last ten years have been the ten warmest on record.

articles.title: Book on climate change released in Hassan
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: A book on climate change, 'Climate Change, Do We Expect These Days', written by noted science writer K.S. Ravi Kumar of Hassan, was released in a programme in Hassan on Sunday. The author recorded the impact of climate change on the farming sector, biodiversity, forest cover, aquatic life and human beings in his book.

articles.title: Here's the ugliest global-warming chart you'll ever need to see
articles.author: Rik Myslewski
articles.summary: According to attribution science, global warming and climate change are exacerbating natural weather cycles. The recent Los Angeles fires were caused by the climate-change-related extreme wet-dry seesaw of southern US weather. Hurricanes Ida and Helene in America, Typhoon Gaemi in the Philippines, and a series of massive floods in South Asia were also caused by climate change. Global warming is increasing at an increasing pace.

articles.title: Thiruvananthapuram records 190 bird species in global bird count; spotlights need for ecological conservation
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: Thiruvananthapuram's capital district documented 190 species through 772 checklists during the Great Backyard Bird Count. India ranked third globally in terms of the number of species documented (1,082) and second for the count of checklists (60,321). Kerala contributed 13,412 checklists covering 347 species as of February 23. The initiative, coordinated by Bird Count India, aims to promote birdwatching and contribute to citizen science.

articles.title: EXPLAINER: What loss and damage fund means for climate action
articles.author: Deborah Bodunde
articles.summary: The loss and damage fund is a financial mechanism designed to support countries devastated by the impacts of climate change. Developed and developing nations are expected to contribute more to the fund in the future. Between 2000 and 2019, the world suffered $2.8 trillion in climate change-related losses costing around $16 million per hour.

articles.title: Homeowners ‘terrified to venture outside' as 5,000 seagulls plague the skies by dropping animal bones in their gardens and making their pets ill with residents living in a perpetual ‘Alfred Hitchcock horror' nightmare
articles.summary: Residents living close to a landfill in Altham, Lancashire, are fed up with seagulls dropping animal bones from the sky. They can't sit in their gardens for fear of being splattered with bird poo and can't hang washing out to dry because of the gulls circling above. One business has lost thousands of pounds after bird waste left some stock unsellable.

articles.title: It's Time to Put More Heat on Global Warming Orthodoxy, Which Itself Offers More Heat Than Light
articles.author: Thomas J Shepstone
articles.summary: Larry Bell is critical of the Green New Scam based on climate pseudoscience science and rent seeking wind/solar industries. According to him, a majority of Americans have lost patience and charity for woke government policies. California's average monthly electricity rates for residential customers have nearly doubled since 2019 due to green energy policies.

articles.title: The climate
articles.author: Jim Davidson
articles.summary: Patrick Moore is a co-founder of Greenpeace. He was protesting the thermonuclear bomb testing on the Amchitka Island in Alaska in 1971. Thomas Malthus predicted great calamities. The aristocrats of Europe have always hated Christianity, hated God and have always been liars.

articles.title: Stephen Fry warns of ‘cult of power' sweeping across the world
articles.author: Camille Chorley
articles.summary: Stephen Fry has warned of a growing global shift toward authoritarianism. He also claimed that Donald Trump has 'contempt' for British politicians and French President Emmanuel Macron. The actor and writer was speaking on Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg (23 February). He is worried by the darkening shadow spreading across the world.

articles.title: Climate Change: Poverty-stricken Patuakhali faces persistent crises
articles.author: Maidul Islam
articles.summary: Climate change has made Patuakhali one of the poorest districts in the country. Livelihoods are being severely affected, school attendance is declining and public health is under threat. People are being forced to either surrender to the combined forces of climate change and poverty or abandon their homeland.

articles.title: Scientists identify tipping point for Greenland's ice sheet — and it's not far off
articles.author: Ben Turner
articles.summary: Greenland's ice sheet is inching toward an irreversible tipping point, after which it will tumble into the ocean, according to a new study published in the journal The Cryosphere. Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets have been losing mass at an accelerated rate due to human-caused climate change.

articles.title: Our village is held hostage by psycho seagulls dropping bones from sky in scenes straight ...
articles.author: The Sun
articles.summary: Residents in Altham, Lancashire, are fed up of being splattered with animal bones from seagulls. They are afraid to go outside because of the noise and the number of birds flying around them. The situation is getting worse all the time.

articles.title: Alarming Crocodile Behaviour Shift Sparks Concern As Climate Change Takes Its Toll
articles.author: Abhinav Singh
articles.summary: Crocodiles in Australia are struggling with increased temperatures due to global warming. Since 2008, the highest crocodile body temperatures have risen by 0.55C. They are less active during the hottest periods, reducing their hunting and feeding time. Some crocodiles have abandoned sunlit basking areas and retreated to deeper, cooler waters.

articles.title: Kashmir sees a major dip in tourists footfall due to dry spell
articles.author: TIMESOFINDIA.COM
articles.summary: Kashmir's tourism industry is going through a low phase due to an unprecedented dry spell. There is a major drop in tourist arrivals and in cancellations. Gulmarg and Pahalgam have seen a 20-30% reduction in business. Bookings have dropped by up to 50%. The worst thing to happen was the postponement of the 2025 Khelo India Winter Games.

articles.title: ESCAP: ASEAN Must Collaborate To Combat Impacts Of Climate Change, Disaster Risk
articles.author: Nabilah Saleh
articles.summary: ESCAP has urged ASEAN to adopt a more coordinated approach to tackling climate change. It warned that worsening climate-related disasters threaten economic and social stability in the region. UN Under-Secretary-General and Executive Secretary of ESCAP Armida Salsiah Alisjahbana visited Malaysia for two-day working visit from Feb 17, 2025.

articles.title: Exploring Nature: Birds & Fire
articles.summary: California forest fires have been in the news recently and fires in Canada have also been destructive. Some birds, especially ground-nesting baby birds, have been burned alive. Many birds will suffer long-term consequences from inhaling smoke. Wildfire smoke is harmful to birds because it contains thousands of chemicals, including nitrogen oxides and chlorinated dioxins.

articles.title: Trough in westerlies from Gangetic West Bengal to South Chattisgarh: Met
articles.author: Uniindia News Service
articles.summary: Saturday's trough in westerlies from Gangetic West Bengal to south Chhattisgarh across Odisha persists. Dry weather is likely to prevail in Coastal Andhra Pradesh & Yanam and Rayalaseema during the next seven days. Maximum temperatures are likely to be above normal by 2-3 degrees Celsius. The lowest minimum temperature of 18.5 degrees Celsius was recorded at Arogyavaram in Rayalasesema on Saturday and Sunday.

articles.title: Light to moderate rain forecast in coastal TN, Puducherry, Karaikkal from Feb 25
articles.author: The Hans India
articles.summary: The Regional Meteorological Centre has forecast light to moderate rainfall in isolated areas of South Coastal Tamil Nadu, the Delta districts, Puducherry, and Karaikal for four days starting February 25. On Sunday, maximum temperatures are projected to be around 32 to 33 degrees Celsius, while minimum temperatures will hover between 23 to 24 degrees Celsius. On Monday, maximum temperature is expected to remain 2 to 3 degrees Celsius above normal. Long-term forecasts indicate that there will be no extreme rise in maximum temperatures during the summer.

articles.title: Carolina Beach subdivision gets approval despite flooding concerns
articles.author: Daniel Sheehan
articles.summary: Fisher's Reserve, a subdivision consisting of nine lots, received preliminary approval at a planning and zoning meeting on Feb. 13. The first phase of the project will add 10 homes to the 5.05-acre plot at 1215 Saint Joseph Street. Two acres of wetlands will remain undisturbed, but the developer has applied for permits to build on the area in the second phase. The surrounding area includes civil war earthworks, or fortifications constructed from dirt, that have been preserved.

articles.title: China slams Australia for 'hyping up' live-fire drills in Tasman Sea
articles.author: Jessica Sier
articles.summary: Australia's naval exercises off the east coast forced commercial flights to divert from trans-Tasman routes on Friday. China's defence ministry has hit back at Australia's response to its naval exercises, labelling Canberra's protests as 'unreasonable' and deliberately inflammatory.

articles.title: 法國幼稚園3歲男童鞋內驚現死老鼠 市長辯稱滅鼠有效遭轟：太離譜
articles.summary: Cities like Washington DC, San Francisco, and NYC are seeing rapid rat population growth due to warmer winters and dense urban living, according to a new study. The study also blames rising temperatures and urban living for the rise in rat population in the U.S.

articles.title: 'Surrounded by an ocean of sand': Desertification pushes ancient city to the brink of oblivion
articles.author: Euronews Green
articles.summary: Chinguetti is one of four UNESCO World Heritage sites in Mauritania, a West African nation where only 0.5% of land is considered farmable. Shifting sands have long covered the ancient city's 8th-century core and are encroaching on neighbourhoods at its current edge. Tree-planting projects are trying to keep the invading sands at bay, but so far, they haven't eased the worries about the future.

articles.title: Climate Change Update: Key Developments Covered Until February 23, 2025
articles.author: archyde
articles.summary: 2014 was the hottest year on record globally, surpassing the previous record set in 2023. Global average temperatures reached 1.55°C above pre-industrial levels. Dr. Elara Hartfield is a renowned climate scientist and lead researcher at the Global Climate Institute. IPCC warns that without deep and rapid cuts to emissions, we could see global temperatures rise by up to 3.6°C by 2100.

articles.title: Navigating Climate Change: The Double-Edged Sword of Risk and Opportunity in Finance
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The increasing threat of climate change is affecting 30% of agricultural and housing loans portfolios over the next five years. Almost half of the credit portfolio of scheduled commercial banks is reliant on natural ecosystems. Climate change presents a lucrative $150 billion investment opportunity annually for India's energy transition efforts.

articles.title: China denies it didn't give timely warning of live-fire drills off Australia
articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.summary: Three planes headed to New Zealand changed course in midflight because of live-fire drills by the Chinese navy. China had issued safety notices in advance and the activity was in compliance with international law. Australia made unreasonable accusations and hyped the situation, China's Defense Ministry said.

articles.title: IOM launches climate resilience programme in Pakistan
articles.summary: The CRHR-BRAVE consortium led by IOM, UNICEF, UNFAO, and IRW, launched the Climate Resilience and Humanitarian Response (CRHR) programme in Pakistan. The project aims to strengthen disaster preparedness, humanitarian response capacities, and long-term climate resilience in Pakistan's most vulnerable regions. It will focus on Sindh, Balochistan and Punjab-three provinces.

articles.title: Death Notice: Glenn Merrill Berry
articles.author: obituaries
articles.summary: Berry, Glenn Merrill 70, of Cape Elizabeth, had no service on February 1st.Comments are not available on this story. Send questions/comments to the editors.  .    "What do you want to add to this story?

articles.title: First-of-its-kind study: How Antarctica's melting ice sheet could change NZ's climate patterns
articles.author: Jamie Morton
articles.summary: New Zealand's proximity to Antarctica and the Southern Ocean has an impact on the climate. The study is the first to look at the specific effects on New Zealand. It found that the meltwater from Antarctica has less warming than otherwise would be observed. The number of hot days over 25C in New Zealand will increase by 27 days per year by the end of the century.

articles.title: 1/4 to 1/2 of Glaciers will Melt by 2100, raising Sea Level, As our burning of Fossil Fuels Heats Earth
articles.author: Juan Cole
articles.summary: Glaciers are losing their ice on average nearly a fifth faster than the Greenland ice sheet and nearly twice as fast as the Antarctic ice sheet. In 2000 to 2023, less than a quarter century, glaciers lost 5% of their ice. The rate of ice loss increased by roughly a fourth to a third in the last decade of the study.

articles.title: Development and its impact on shorebirds in Anguilla
articles.author: Flora Thomas
articles.summary: There are significant declines in shorebird populations in the Caribbean. Birding enthusiast Jackie Cestero is concerned about the impact of tourism-related development in Anguilla. The Anguillan government has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to develop 87 hectares of coastal land for Savannah Bay resort.

articles.title: Lithium, Minerals & Gold Are In Those Mountains--The USA INC- Blackrock & Vanguard Want Your Land!
articles.author: Alicia Lutz-Rolow
articles.summary: There is no need to believe in human weather manipulation conspiracy theories. They have been doing it for decades and are far more advanced now than before. The Dimming, Full-Length Climate Engineering Documentary ( Geoengineering Watch) is a good place to start.

articles.title: World's fastest-moving continent Australia is heading for a collision with Asia, Is India, Pakistan at risk? Scientists say...
articles.author: support@india.com
articles.summary: Australia is moving northward at a rate of 2.8 inches (7 cm) per year. Professor Zheng-Xiang Li of Curtin University believes the Australian continent is going to collide with Asia. In 2016, Australia had to update its official GPS coordinates by 1.8 meters (5.9 feet) to maintain accuracy.

articles.title: World's Fastest-Moving Continent Australia Is Heading for a Collision With Asia, Is India, Pakistan at Risk? Scientists say...
articles.summary: Australia is moving northward at a rate of 2.8 inches (7 cm) per year. The movement is part of a cyclical pattern, where continents drift apart and then eventually come back together. The Indo-Australian Plate, which carries Australia, will eventually collide with Asia. The collision will alter the region's landscape, climate, and biodiversity.

articles.title: Australia second for shark bites as numbers fall worldwide
articles.author: Erin Blakemore
articles.summary: Australia recorded the second highest number of unprovoked shark bites last year. Seven people were bitten by sharks last year, seven of them fatally, according to the International Shark Attack File. That number was down from 69 bites in 2023, when 10 incidents were fatal. The fatal attacks were recorded in Hawaii in the United States, the Maldives, Egypt and in open ocean off Western Sahara.

articles.title: ‘Climate change bad for business, needs everyones efforts to address'
articles.author: Mayson Luis
articles.summary: Jacob Ekinye is the Director of Building Resilience to Climate Change (BRCC) Project. He was speaking at the procurement signing with Sport Fishing PNG, to donate the four passenger boats to the four islands in the AROB. He urged everyone (individuals and businesses alike) to take a bold step forward and rise up to the challenges.

articles.title: 冰川融化警報！全球23年流失6.5兆噸冰 海平面上升2釐米恐釀災難
articles.summary: Glaciers lost 6.5 trillion tons of ice since 2000, raising sea levels by 18mm. Alaska and the Alps are among the worst affected areas. Urgent action is needed to curb greenhouse gas emissions, according to climate change experts.

articles.title: Meltdown metrics
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Evidence suggests sustained global warming at or beyond 1.5 degrees Celsius, the limit set by the Paris Agreement, is approaching a critical threshold, according to the scientists. The Earth is approaching that threshold now.   .   i   in the future.

articles.title: Meltdown metrics
articles.author: Quratulain Siddiqui
articles.summary: Evidence suggests sustained global warming at or beyond 1.5°C is approaching a critical threshold. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change outlines feasible pathways to limit warming, including peaking emissions by 2025 and halving them by 2030. The path forward requires systemic shifts, phasing out fossil fuels, overhauling energy infrastructure, and delivering climate finance without delay.

articles.title: The 'Degrowth' Movement's Push for Climate Justice
articles.author: Mike Miller
articles.summary: 'Degrowth' emerged in Europe, particularly in France, in the late 2000s. It is a radical alternative to 'green growth', which aims to continue expanding economies while minimising environmental harm. Critics argue that degrowth is unattractive for the global south.

articles.title: What Really Sets The Global Climate State?
articles.author: Schlaht
articles.summary: The Million Year Ice Core Project (MYIC) is preparing to drill the oldest continuous ice core record from Antarctica in 2025. This record will help solve a long-standing mystery about the timing and duration of past 'ice ages' detected in marine sediment cores. The theory that declining atmospheric CO2 levels were the cause of the longer, colder ice expansions was wrong.

articles.title: CLIMATE CHANGE: PAKISTAN'S CLIMATE BLIND SPOT
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Pakistan is the fifth most vulnerable country to climate change in the world. In 2022, 33 million people will be displaced, over 1,700 lives lost, and a third of the country submerged due to biblical floods.    in 2022's biblical floods 33 million were displaced and over 1.700 people died.

articles.title: CLIMATE CHANGE: PAKISTAN'S CLIMATE BLIND SPOT
articles.author: Sheheryar Khan
articles.summary: Pakistan is the fifth most vulnerable country to climate change. The national conversation on climate change needs to move from conference halls to the public and civil society. The communication gap between scientific knowledge and public engagement needs to be broken. Climate resilience cannot be built through top-down policies alone, it must be informed by those whose survival depends on it.

articles.title: Hot winds heighten risk as bushfires rage, bans issued
articles.author: Adrian Black
articles.summary: Wild winds are fanning dangerous fire conditions across Australia's southeast. Fire crews are on alert and on the lookout for the blazes.   in the area are on firefighting alert as a result of the winds. The blazes are burning in the south east.

articles.title: Here's the ugliest global-warming chart you'll ever need to see
articles.author: The Register
articles.summary: Earth is running a fever, but it's surprising how fast its temperature is rising.   It's not news that Earth has a fever. It's surprising that it's rising so fast. it's also surprising how high the temperature is. It is very fast.

articles.title: Abia embarks on mainstreaming climate change actions in forest reserves
articles.author: Business Day Online
articles.summary: Abia State Government has embarked on mainstreaming of climate change actions within all relevant sectors of the economy. Philemon explains this to Abia's governor, Okonjo-Iyarwandu. He also talks about climate change in forest reserves.

articles.title: Study Finds Glaciers Are Melting Faster Than Ever
articles.author: OWP
articles.summary: A recent study found that glaciers worldwide are melting faster than previously thought, having lost 5% of their ice since 2000. According to the United Nations University, we are projected to lose around 50% of glaciers by 2100, even if global warming can be limited to 1.5°C.

articles.title: Climate change speeds up glacier melt
articles.author: Record
articles.summary: Climate change is accelerating the melting of the world's mountain glaciers, according to a new study. The glaciers are shrinking more than twice as fast as in the early 2000s, the study found.      Â  .   in the

articles.title: The heat is on, and it's posing a threat to our health
articles.author: Business Line
articles.summary: The planet reached a critical milestone in 2024. Each of the last 10 years was the hottest on record. The global average temperature is rising, exceeding the Paris Climate Accord's target. Extreme heat is a silent killer, exacerbating chronic conditions and overwhelming the human body.

articles.title: 'Rising temperature may increase probability of default in 30% of agri loan portfolio by 2030'
articles.author: Business Line
articles.summary: Rising temperature and growing threat of climate change may increase default risk in 30 per cent of agri and housing loans portfolio in the next five years, according to BCG analysis by BCG. BCG says climate change is a major threat to the economy.

articles.title: Coffee prices are at a 50-year high. Producers aren't celebrating.
articles.author: Japan Times
articles.summary: Around the world, coffee traders, farmers and roasters fear how climate change and economic factors will affect their livelihoods.   .   in this article we have referred to the article "Coffee Traders, Farmers and Roasters Fear Climate Change and Economic Factors".

articles.title: China denies it didn't give timely warning of live-fire drills off Australia
articles.author: ABC News
articles.summary: Three planes headed to New Zealand changed course in midflight because of live-fire drills by the Chinese navy. China's Defense Ministry says that Australia made 'unreasonable accusations' and deliberately hyped the situation after the planes changed course due to the drills.

articles.title: Nations at odds over major UN climate science report
articles.author: GREG BAKER
articles.summary: Representatives of nearly 200 countries gather in Hangzhou on Monday to continue negotiations on the timing and content of the UN's next blockbuster assessment of global warming science. The meeting comes on the heels of the hottest year on record and rising alarm over the pace of warming.

articles.title: JIM 'PAPPY' MOORE: Colder Than a Well Digger's Behind
articles.summary: It's been very cold in Texas this winter. Jim Moore is not a fan of global warming. He prefers the weather in Texas to be predictable. He likes it when there is a sunny day in the 60s for Thanksgiving or Christmas. Every few years Texas has a snowfall around Christmas or New Year's.
